Introduction

Since my childhood, I've frequently encountered phrases incorporating the word "time". One classic expression that was echoed by various adults was: "the time is over". Another, a more poetic rendering, often heard among people (Rodrigues, W., Soares Filho, A. C., Vale, M. S. do, & Menezes, M. C., 2023, pp. 12):

• The time asked for time: what time does time possess?
    The time responded, it does not have time to say
    the remaining time within time is the time available.

If you've had any involvement with 'Abrahamic religions' (Guy G. Stroumsa, 2011) at any point in your life, you might be familiar with Ecclesiastes chapter 3, which states that there is a "time for every pursuit under the heavens", illustrated with examples of different periods of time (Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, 1891, pp. 876 - 877 ).

Reflexion 1: A question
All the preceding references have one thing in common: they allude to time, yet none offers a precise definition. So, what exactly is time?

The understanding about time

The comprehension of time has evolved over millennia, as explored by G. N. Bailey in his work (Bailey, G. N., 1983). . Within his discourse:
  • Pages 167 to 174 introduce a potential duality in understanding the universe and time's role in our lives.
  • On page 179, Bailey challenges conventional notions of the "present" and the "past", emphasizing temporal variations ranging from fleeting moments to millennia.
  • Pages 180 to 186 prompt us to consider vast time spans, such as the 100,000-year "glacial-interglacial cycle" alongside shorter periods like decades, underscoring time as a succession of events.
  • Page 187 notes that around 30,000 years ago, human intellectual development allowed for activities oriented towards the future.

It's crucial to note that the ability to project into the future doesn't necessarily entail a constant focus in that direction, as Jaakko Hintikka illustrates in his analysis of Greek concepts of time (Hintikka, J., 1967, pp. 1 - 5, 14), highlighting the Greeks' deep immersion in the present.

Furthermore, defining periods of time linked to natural processes presents significant challenges (Bailey, G. N., 1983, pp. 180 - 186). Ancient civilizations, in attempting to map the past, often attributed implausible durations to historical figures (Steenstrup, Troels, et al., 2017), such as Sumerian kings with millennial reigns (History Tracers, 2024 ; History with Cy, 2021, 05:09). Millennia later, the Jewish tradition continued this trend, assigning patriarchs lifespans of centuries (Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, 1891, pp. 7 - 8 ). These temporal discrepancies, contrasting with our lived experiences, differ markedly from Mesoamerican conceptions, as elaborated below (Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, 1981, pp. 175).

Time Measurement

The measurement of time has always been crucial throughout human history, enabling us to determine the optimal moment for activities such as planting crops or births. In this section, we will delve into the Mesoamerican approach to time measurement.

The Maya calendar, along with those of other Mesoamerican cultures, was intricately linked with mathematics (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 33 - 35 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 33 - 35 (Revista)). Similar to the Gregorian calendar, Mesoamerican calendars divided time into specific periods:

PeriodsDescription
DayRepresents the time needed for the Earth to complete one rotation around its axis.
MonthComprised of periods of 20 days, with one period containing only 5 days to correct the solar year.
Tzolkín calendar (divinatory)A cycle of 260 days (13 x 20 = 260).
Haab calendar (civil)Consisting of 365 days (18 x 20 + 5 = 365).
Calendar wheelA cycle of 52 years where the Haab and Tzolkín calendars return to the same position, symbolizing the end of a cycle.
Table 1: Periods of Mesoamerican Time.
The Zapotecs also employed an additional division known as the "divinatory calendar", consisting of 4 periods of 65 days (Trejo, Jesús G., 2009, pp. 20).
While not all eras are represented in the Aztecs' Sun Stone, it provides a visual representation of the previously discussed concepts (Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, 1981, pp. 175):

Figure 1: Aztec Calendar on display at the National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City (Museo Nacional de Antropologia - México ; INAH - MX, 2023).
Photo taken on October 18, 2016, during a museum visit.

Furthermore, Mesoamericans developed additional structures to monitor the seasons of the year, known as E groups (Guderjan, T. H., 2006). These complex structures typically featured a pyramid with at least two additional buildings positioned ahead of it. The layout allowed for the observation of key celestial events: the summer solstice on the extreme left, the beginning of equinoxes in the center, and the winter solstice on the extreme right.

Figure 2: Section of the E Group at the Caracol archaeological site (Caracol Archaeological Project).
Photo taken on July 26, 2016, during a site visit.

The genesis of time

One captivating aspect of the Maya calendar, along with those of other Mesoamerican civilizations, is their establishment of an origin point that traces back to the last "creation of the universe". This significant event is marked as August 13th, 3114 B.C., according to the Gregorian calendar (Graulich, Michel, 1995 ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 29 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 29 (Revista)). The precise delineation of this starting point places these calendars ahead of many contemporary systems. Consequently, astronomical studies often adopt the Julian calendar due to its structural similarities with the Mesoamerican system (Julian Date Converter).

Research by Orlando Josué C. Contreras .et al. demonstrates that when utilizing the long count, the order of magnitudes does not strictly adhere to the base 20; adjustments are necessary (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 34 (ResearchGate) ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, 2022, pp. 34 (Revista)). Furthermore, Mesoamerican calendars exhibit coherent cycles spanning millennia, a feature absent in Western worldviews (Ocampo, Estela; Bidon-Chanal, Carlos, 1981, pp. 175).
